ul: For more information about protecting log files on Linux, please see http://answers.oreilly.com/topic/424-how-to-protect-our-logs-fromtampering/For more information about protecting log files on BSD, please see http://www.bsdguides.org/guides/freebsd/security/harden.phpFor more information about protecting logs on Windows, please see http://support.microsoft.com/kb/308419For information about the set_error_handler function, please see http://us.php.net/manual/en/function.set-error-handler.phpFor information about the syslog function, please see http://php.net/manual/en/function.syslog.php

Centralize Logging
      
        Protect Log Files
        
          Log Important Event Details
          
            Do Not Log Sensitive Information
            
              Log Important Security Operations
              
                Log Unusual Activity
                
                  Log Important Business Operations
                  
                    Monitor the Use of Privileged Accounts
                    
                      Log Authentication Events

Logging Is Centralized
      
        Log Files Are Protected
        
          Important Event Details Are Logged
          
            Sensitive Information Is Not Logged
            
              Important Security Operations Are Logged
              
                Unusual Activity Is Logged
                
                  Important Business Operations Are Logged
                  
                    The Use of Privileged Accounts Is Monitored
                    
                      Authentication Events Are Logged
li: Avoid disclosing location of logs. The location of the log files should be known only by your application and its administrators. Avoid disclosing the location of the logs to users.
Set appropriate file permissions. Set the file system permissions so that only your application and its administrators/developers have access to its logs.

Keep the logging framework away from users. Do not allow your application's users to interact directly with the logging framework. The logging framework should log information regarding the performance of the application but should avoid storing user-supplied data inside the logs. Some user-supplied information can aid an attacker into poisoning your application's logs.

Consider using log rotation. Log rotation prevents your application from working with large log files. It allows you to manage and audit your application's logged events without interfering in your application's workings. Use the following steps when utilizing log rotation:
            
              
                
                  Define a rotation period: Schedule your log rotation on a regular basis. For example, rotate your logs every Monday. 
                
                  
                    Create a new log file: Create a new log file when your application needs to rotate its log files. Major operating systems allow a file to only be appended to (not read or modified).
                  
                    
                      Back up the existing log files: Back up the existing log files when your application needs to rotate its log files. Consult your internal auditing policy to determine the period for which logs should be backed up. If your application backs up its logs, store them into an environment that is as secure as the storage environment for the current logs. Note: PCI DSS requirements state that logs should be kept for at least one year.
Define a rotation period: Schedule your log rotation on a regular basis. For example, rotate your logs every Monday.
Create a new log file: Create a new log file when your application needs to rotate its log files. Major operating systems allow a file to only be appended to (not read or modified).

Back up the existing log files: Back up the existing log files when your application needs to rotate its log files. Consult your internal auditing policy to determine the period for which logs should be backed up. If your application backs up its logs, store them into an environment that is as secure as the storage environment for the current logs. Note: PCI DSS requirements state that logs should be kept for at least one year.

Consider using an external logging application. Using an external logging application ensures that your application's logs will be kept up-to-date even if your application abruptly terminates. Use a custom error handler that calls syslog to deliver error messages, configuring syslog securely. On windows, this goes to the event log.

Consider encoding output that is sent to log files. This can be useful in preventing log forging. Stripping out certain characters [\r\n] that are known to create new lines, which can allow an attacker to forge log entries.
For more information about protecting log files on Linux, please see http://answers.oreilly.com/topic/424-how-to-protect-our-logs-fromtampering/
For more information about protecting log files on BSD, please see http://www.bsdguides.org/guides/freebsd/security/harden.php
For more information about protecting logs on Windows, please see http://support.microsoft.com/kb/308419
For information about the set_error_handler function, please see http://us.php.net/manual/en/function.set-error-handler.php
For information about the syslog function, please see http://php.net/manual/en/function.syslog.php
Monitor the Use of Privileged Accounts
The Use of Privileged Accounts Is Monitored

a: Monitor the Use of Privileged Accounts
The Use of Privileged Accounts Is Monitored

links.text: Monitor the Use of Privileged Accounts
The Use of Privileged Accounts Is Monitored

html:
Applies to

  • PHP

What to Do

Restrict access to the log files protect your application from attackers, as well as to protect your users' confidential information.

Why

Log files often contain internal application details that could enable an attacker to more effectively target your application.

How

Use the following steps to protect the application's log files:

  1. Avoid disclosing location of logs. The location of the log files should be known only by your application and its administrators. Avoid disclosing the location of the logs to users.

  2. Set appropriate file permissions. Set the file system permissions so that only your application and its administrators/developers have access to its logs.

  3. Keep the logging framework away from users. Do not allow your application's users to interact directly with the logging framework. The logging framework should log information regarding the performance of the application but should avoid storing user-supplied data inside the logs. Some user-supplied information can aid an attacker into poisoning your application's logs.

  4. Consider using log rotation. Log rotation prevents your application from working with large log files. It allows you to manage and audit your application's logged events without interfering in your application's workings. Use the following steps when utilizing log rotation:

    1. Define a rotation period: Schedule your log rotation on a regular basis. For example, rotate your logs every Monday.

    2. Create a new log file: Create a new log file when your application needs to rotate its log files. Major operating systems allow a file to only be appended to (not read or modified).

    3. Back up the existing log files: Back up the existing log files when your application needs to rotate its log files. Consult your internal auditing policy to determine the period for which logs should be backed up. If your application backs up its logs, store them into an environment that is as secure as the storage environment for the current logs.
      Note: PCI DSS requirements state that logs should be kept for at least one year.

  5. Consider using an external logging application. Using an external logging application ensures that your application's logs will be kept up-to-date even if your application abruptly terminates. Use a custom error handler that calls syslog to deliver error messages, configuring syslog securely. On windows, this goes to the event log.

  6. Consider encoding output that is sent to log files. This can be useful in preventing log forging. Stripping out certain characters [\r\n] that are known to create new lines, which can allow an attacker to forge log entries.

Additional Resources

  • For more information about protecting log files on Linux, please see http://answers.oreilly.com/topic/424-how-to-protect-our-logs-fromtampering/
  • For more information about protecting log files on BSD, please see http://www.bsdguides.org/guides/freebsd/security/harden.php
  • For more information about protecting logs on Windows, please see http://support.microsoft.com/kb/308419
  • For information about the set_error_handler function, please see http://us.php.net/manual/en/function.set-error-handler.php
  • For information about the syslog function, please see http://php.net/manual/en/function.syslog.php

Logging Guidelines

  • Centralize Logging
  • Protect Log Files
  • Log Important Event Details
  • Do Not Log Sensitive Information
  • Log Important Security Operations
  • Log Unusual Activity
  • Log Important Business Operations
  • Monitor the Use of Privileged Accounts
  • Log Authentication Events

Logging Checklists

  • Logging Is Centralized
  • Log Files Are Protected
  • Important Event Details Are Logged
  • Sensitive Information Is Not Logged
  • Important Security Operations Are Logged
  • Unusual Activity Is Logged
  • Important Business Operations Are Logged
  • The Use of Privileged Accounts Is Monitored
  • Authentication Events Are Logged
